comment_data.body:
If it can help, when I hard code something like that i get $responce->status = "created".

$response = $this->getResponse('https://v.whatsapp.net/v2/exist?cc=41&in=79xxxxxx&udid=35xxxxxxxxxx');
JSON Response contains id as one of the attributes. Could it be replacement for pw attribute?

@sricoder no, 
id does refer to pw, but in the above example stated by @arontunzi it is only udid, which is like imei for iPhone

Hi All, please @arontunzi  did you find the solution, if yes please share it with us.

Thanks.
I didn't want to mess with my registration, but I guess I'll look into it when I get home.. :/

I've set up Apache with a self-signed certificate, added it to my hosts file on my device and installed the certificate on my device. After that I was able to pull this from my access log:

    [16/Apr/2013:00:14:57 +0200] 192.168.2.3 TLSv1 RC4-SHA "GET /v2/exist?cc=31&in=62*******&lg=nl&lc=NL&id=%a5f%b1%a7%e22Q%c6Kn%93%98%9c%8d%7e%7d%2b%d5%ffY HTTP/1.1" 6
Looks like url-encoded binary data.
So the challenge now is to reproduce the id string using my IMEI... :(

And it's past midnight already x( FML

UPDATE
I've setup my spare Android device to view requests from whatsapp so I can share the IMEI code I used:

    352666044830596

We all assumed that the identity is created from the IMEI code or MAC address. I've tried different phonenumbers with the same IMEI code just to be sure, and sure enough the hash changed!
Here are 3 requests using the IMEI above. Each request has a different number:

    [16/Apr/2013:01:14:32 +0200] 192.168.2.5 TLSv1 RC4-SHA "GET /v2/exist?cc=31&in=629445136&lg=nl&lc=NL&id=U%20%28LF%9c%21n%25t4%b6%b7%dcVj%dd%12%9c%99 HTTP/1.1" 6
    [16/Apr/2013:01:16:16 +0200] 192.168.2.5 TLSv1 RC4-SHA "GET /v2/exist?cc=31&in=629445135&lg=nl&lc=NL&id=%9ey%d0%93%13%85%0e%9d%f9E%25V%08%e1%15%40%09u5%1c HTTP/1.1" 6
    [16/Apr/2013:01:16:55 +0200] 192.168.2.5 TLSv1 RC4-SHA "GET /v2/exist?cc=31&in=650568134&lg=nl&lc=NL&id=%bc%fc%5f%e8%fc%d9R%bc4G%c3%9a%0a%bc%dex%83%cc%819 HTTP/1.1" 6
So it appears they've changed the identity hashing algorithm. I've tested yowsup already, which is also broken at the moment.

I'm gonna give it a quick shot and then go to bed to hopefully catch a few hours of proper sleep :(

EDIT:
Well no luck so far..
For those who care, this is where the magic happens:
![Batcave](http://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/68235039/2013-04-16%2001.30.52.jpg)

same for here. 

news?
No news yet, I was hoping that someone else might pick this up as well. I'm a bit stumped by this, trying to take a break from PHP by writing a little Android exploit app :/

News:
https://github.com/shirioko/WhatSNiff
:)
The app uses a new identity hash so /v2/exist won't work for numbers registered using the official app. You can still intercept the password by using my proxy though.

From what I've been told by @manufuentescr numbers registered from this API (or similar like yowsup) still work with /v2/exist because they use the same identity hash.
Exactly, the problem is that it smells like a new version, probably very soon they will not accept the registered numbers from this API, hopefully this will not happen XD

Can you make the change I mentioned and test if requestCode() and checkCredentials() still work with urlencoded MD5 hash? :D
If so, you can update the code to always use the new identity hash.

Of course checkCredentials() doesn't work, your registered identity is still 

    md5(strrev($imei))
You'll have to use requestCode() first using the urlencoded identity ;)

EDIT:
You don't get the error "Bad param: id" so WhatsApp does accept the new identity :)

WhatsApp doesn't send our IMEI codes to the server, just the phonenumbers and identities generated from it. This means that they cannot recreate and validate our identity and that we can send just about any identity we want as long as the format is correct.

So checkCredentials will work as long as the number is registered using this API (as long as identity used for requestCode and checkCredentials is the same). 
If we want checkCredentials to work with numbers registered using the mobile app we'll have to recreate their new hashing method..
it works, but first you must use requestCode (), you're right, the problem is that I would have to  register the numbers again, these work with md5 (strrev ($ imei))

Well that's one way to piss off a bunch of people ^^

I think that we shouldn't change identity generation for now, but we should keep it in mind though in case WhatsApp decides to flip the switch :)

Hello! Then, how is the easy way to register a number????

Where can i read the information???

Saludos Jesús Sales

El 19/04/2013, a las 17:42, Max Kovaljov <notifications@github.com> escribió:

> Well that's one way to piss off a bunch of people ^^
> 
> I think that we shouldn't change identity generation for now, but we should keep it in mind though in case WhatsApp decides to flip the switch :)
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Hola jesus la manera mas facil para mi es registrar los numeros con el API.

Hi jesus the easiest way for me is register the numbers with the API.
Yes @shirioko  we have to take in mind for a future update! great find ^^

Ok, mirare como se hace, gracias por responder en español...

Ok, thanks a lot, now i'll comming to look up about is The method

Saludos Jesús Sales

El 19/04/2013, a las 18:05, manufuentescr <notifications@github.com> escribió:

> Hola jesus la manera mas facil para mi es registrar los numeros con el API.
> 
> Hi jesus the easiest way for me is register the numbers with the API.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Anyone willing to give this a go? :)
https://github.com/shirioko/MissVenom

I've been playing around with SSL proxies recently to capture passwords and a couple of days ago I created WhatSNiff in PHP, pretty basic proof-of-concept stuff running in a regular webserver. Today I created a standalone SSL proxy in C# (.NET 4 or 4.5 required). Download and run the .exe, install certificate on device, add hosts entry on device and register WhatsApp on your device. Four simple steps.

checkCredentials() still works perfectly for numbers registered using the official app, the problem is the new identity which we cannot reproduce.

MissVenom displays the request as well as the response so you'll have your password to log in as well as your new identity to request a new password if needed!

![MissVenom](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/68235039/proxy.png)

Oh WOW.

Away all this week, but I'll be looking at this definitely @shirioko - great idea/job!!

FYI :)
https://github.com/shirioko/WhatsAPI/commit/5ed20d62e494677caa8a3591aff8776054f3e7a7
Login() now accepts a custom identity as argument. This allows it to use checkCredentials() to retrieve a new password using the new identity format (see my comment https://github.com/venomous0x/WhatsAPI/issues/283#issuecomment-16415346)
We can use the identity generated by the phone until we have cracked the new algorithm for generating the new identities. The identity can be intercepted using either MissVenom or WhatSNiff.

title: Entered the right information (Nr + IMEI) but bad credential.
